data.title: McGillivray, Joan (1863-1948)
data.meta_description: Joan McGillivrary was the widow of John McGillivray. She lived at 1915 Pendrell Street from 1918 to about 1929.   Life in Scotland Joan McGillivrary was born Joan McKay on November 6, 1863 on the island of Eigg, one of the Small Isles off the west coast of Scotland. (Her name sometimes appears with two…
data.text:
Joan McGillivrary was the widow of John McGillivray. She lived at 1915 Pendrell Street from 1918 to about 1929.

Life in Scotland

Joan McGillivrary was born Joan McKay on November 6, 1863 on the island of Eigg, one of the Small Isles off the west coast of Scotland. (Her name sometimes appears with two “n”s: Joann.)

She was married to John McGillivray, who was born at Stornoway, Scotland. He worked as a builder, and it appears that he died between 1891 and 1901.

In 1901, Joan was living in Falkirk, Stirlingshire, with three children: Annabella, Anne and John.

To Canada

In 1911, Joan sailed to Canada, along with Annabella, Annie and John. Joan’s immigration document indicated that she had been a district nurse in Scotland.

Joan first appeared in the Vancouver directories in 1912. She was living at 35 East Lansdowne Avenue in Vancouver’s Mount Pleasant area.

Joan and other members of her family lived at the following addresses in Vancouver from 1912 to 1929.

1912 35 East Lansdowne Avenue 1913 1855 Pandora Street (Annabella McGillivray) 1913 1731 Pandora Street (as Mrs. Joan MacGillvray: “Mac,” not “Mc.”) 1914 2737 East Second Avenue (Miss A. McGillivray and Mrs. J. McGillivray; also Alex Mulholland, who married Annabella Mulholland in January 1914). 1915 2737 East Second Avenue (Miss A. McGillivray and Alex Mulholland) 1916 1636 Victoria Drive (Annie McGillivray, Mrs. John McGillivrary and Alex Mulholland [active service]) 1917 1636 Victoria Drive (Annie McGillivray, Mrs. John McGillivrary and Mrs. A. Mulholland) 1918 to 1929 1915 Pendrell Street

In 1929, Joan travelled from Vancouver to Washington State. She was visiting with her son, John, who was living in Spokane, Washington.

Joann died in North Vancouver, British Columbia on May 7, 1948. She was buried in the Masonic Cemetery in Burnaby, British Columbia.

Joan had the following children.

Annabella McGillivray

Annabella McGillivray was born in Falkirk, Stirlingshire, Scotland on June 23, 1891.

In 1901 she was living with her mother in Falkirk.

In 1911 she travelled to Canada with her mother.

On January 28, 1914, in Vancouver, she married Alexander Mulholland, who was a carpenter. He was born on April 18, 1889 at Kilmory on the island of Arran in Buteshire, Scotland. His parents were Alexander Mulholland and Catherine Downie.

On September 9, 1915, in Vancouver, Alexander signed his attestation papers to serve with the Canadian Expeditionary Force during the First World War.

He was killed on October 8, 1916, during the Battle of the Somme.

His name appears on the Vimy Memorial at Pas de Calais, France, as well as on a war memorial at the Ross Road intersection, between Sliddery and Lagg on the island of Arran, Scotland.

In 1921, Annabella and her son, Gordon, were living with Annabella’s mother at 1915 Pendrell Street.

Annabella died in Vancouver on March 6, 1946. She was buried in the Masonic Cemetery in Burnaby, British Columbia.

Annabella and Alexander had a son, Gordon Alexander Mulholland (1915-1991).

Anne Robertson McGillivray

Anne Robertson McGillivray was born in Falkirk, Stirlingshire, Scotland on January 9, 1897.

In 1901 she was living with her mother in Falkirk.

In 1911 she travelled to Canada with her mother.

In 1921 she was living with her mother at 1915 Pendrell Street in Vancouver.

In April 1926, Anne became engaged to John R. Ross.

John Ross was a commission agent with Frederick A. Tasker.

John was born in Glasgow, Scotland on February 10, 1895. His parents were John Ross and Isabella Graham. The wedding was in Vancouver on April 29, 1926.

The marriage was not successful. By 1927, Anne was again living at 1915 Pendrell Street, while John remained at his former home on Broadway.

In 1928, Anne’s directory listing called her “Anne McG Ross.”

By 1929, Anne was using her maiden name.

In April 1929, Anne went to Spokane, Washington.

In 1951, she declared her intention to become a naturalized United States citizen.

In 1952 she was living with her brother, John, in Spokane. She was an assistant with Filiatrault’s gift shop.

Anne died in North Vancouver, British Columbia on November 30, 1990.

John Ross’s Marriage to Cecile

On July 25, 1934 in Vancouver, John Ross married Marie Cecilia Desrosiers, who was a school teacher. (She was often called “Cecile.”) She was born in Vancouver on January 12, 1903. Her parents were Magloire Desrosiers and Marie Caroline Boeur.

John died on May 10, 1956.

On November 12, 1966, in Vancouver, Cecile married Vernon Kiltz.

Vernon died on August 25, 1975.

Marie died on February 25, 1998.

John McGillivray

John McGillivray was born in Falkirk, Stirlingshire, Scotland on May 4, 1899. (He sometimes spelled his surname as “MacGillivray.”)

In 1901 he was living with his mother in Falkirk.

In 1911, he travelled to Canada with his mother and his two sisters.

He worked as an insurance clerk.

On May 27, 1918, in Esquimalt, British Columbia, he signed his attestation paper to serve with the Canadian Expeditionary Force during the First World War.

He was discharged from the military forces on December 23, 1918, during the demobilization at the end of the war.

In 1921, he was living with his mother at 1915 Pendrell Street in Vancouver.

On April 7, 1927 he moved to the United States and, by June 1927, he was in Spokane, Washington, where he became a fire insurance adjuster.

On December 25, 1930, in Spokane, he married Orlena Hammond, who was a bacteriologist. (Her first name sometimes appears as “Orleana.”) She was born in Spokane on August 5, 1899. Her parents were William Charles Hammond (1871-1925) and Susan Cecelia Schearer (1878-after 1940).

In 1933, John petitioned to become a naturalized United States citizen.

John was an insurance adjuster until the 1950s.

John died on January 3, 1956, in Ritzville, Adams County, Washington.

Orlena died in Spokane on November 8, 1967.
